channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Italian Prime Minister Calls Populism a Threat to Stability in Europe
item.description: In an interview, Prime Minister Enrico Letta said the rise of angry populism could undermine efforts to build and strengthen the euro zone’s political and financial institutions.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Enrico Letta, arriving by car for a political meeting in Rome last April, just days before he was sworn in as Italy’s prime minister.

item.title: Major Earthquake Strikes Central Philippines
item.description: The quake damaged major buildings in Cebu City, a heavily populated commercial center in the central Philippines.
item.dc:creator: By FLOYD WHALEY

item.title: Bulgaria’s Air Is Dirtiest in Europe, Study Finds, Followed by Poland
item.description: Bulgaria has the highest levels of two kinds of particulate matter that can lead to health problems from asthma to cancer, the European Union says in an environmental study.
item.dc:creator: By DANNY HAKIM
item.media:description: Smokestacks last February in Sofia, Bulgaria. A European study found that Bulgaria had the highest levels of two kinds of particulate matter that can lead to health problems from asthma to cancer.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Embracing the Perceived Freedom of R.V.’s
item.description: Recreational vehicles might have middle-brow associations in the United States, but in China they are seen as an upholstered magic carpet, toilet included, that provides an escape.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: Fashion Police Take on Cabbies
item.description: Officers are being deployed in a northern state to arrest people wearing what is deemed to be “indecent dress,” a representative of an Islamic agency said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: China: 6-Year Term for Protester in Blast
item.description: A court in Beijing sentenced a man to six years in prison after finding him guilty of detonating a homemade bomb in Beijing’s Capital International Airport in July, state-run news media reported.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Ethiopia: 2 Men Killed While Preparing a Bomb for an Attack, an Official Says
item.description: The explosion took place Sunday afternoon as thousands were gathering in the capital, Addis Ababa, to watch a World Cup qualifying soccer game between Ethiopia and Nigeria
item.dc:creator: By BENNO MUCHLER

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: American Hurt in Hotel Blast
item.description: It was not immediately clear what had caused the explosion at the 22-story Trader’s Hotel, but it was the latest in a series of unexplained blasts around the country.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Tourists Rescued on Mt. Everest
item.description: Chinese rescuers had evacuated 86 tourists trapped by heavy snowfall at the north base camp of Mount Everest, according to Xinhua, the state news agency.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: As China Moves to Lower Professor’s Profile, Colleges Are Seeking to Raise Theirs
item.description: Government efforts to silence a Peking University professor who has criticized Communist rule come as China’s colleges are ambitiously seeking respect abroad as great centers of learning.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: Xia Yeliang, an economics professor at Peking University, at home in Beijing last month. He says he expects to be fired for criticizing the ruling Communist Party in his writings and in the classroom.

item.title: Malaysian Court Restricts Use of ‘Allah’ to Muslims
item.description: A three-judge panel ruled that non-Muslims may not use the word to refer to God, citing concerns of a threat to Islam.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER

item.title: To Form German Coalition, Merkel’s Party May Need to Support a Minimum Wage
item.description: Although Chancellor Angela Merkel is against introducing a nationwide minimum wage, it may be the price she has to pay to build the stable government she has promised voters.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel and other Christian Democrats arrived for talks with the Social Democrats on Monday in Berlin.

item.title: Hong Kong Journal: Modern Subways Zip Below, but a City’s Trams, Slow and Sweaty, Plod On
item.description: Hong Kong’s 109-year-old tram system manages to compete with the speedier subway, in part because riders like its convenience and rock-bottom cost.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: A tram moved through a market on Saturday in Hong Kong. The trams draw 200,000 riders a day for a price of 2.30 Hong Kong dollars, or 30 cents, a ride, regardless of the distance traveled.

item.title: A Proposed Movie Deal for a Piracy Suspect Has a Surprise Ending: His Arrest
item.description: A suspect behind a 2009 attack on a Belgian ship was lured to Brussels with an offer to make a film about his piracy past, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS and NICHOLAS KULISH

item.title: No Quarter for Former SS Captain, Reviled Even in Death
item.description: Officials in Argentina, Germany and Italy have blocked the burial of Erich Priebke, who was sentenced for helping to organize the execution of 335 civilians in Rome in 1944.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:description: Erich Priebke entering a military court in Rome in 1996. He died on Friday at 100. Officials in Rome have blocked a funeral.

item.title: In New Nuclear Talks, Technological Gains by Iran Pose Challenges to the West
item.description: An American official said the United States and its partners would wait for Iran to take concrete steps to constrain the pace and scope of its nuclear program before easing any sanctions.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: A woman looks at a sculpture of a naked man, which was covered by a curtain at the entrance to the meeting hall at the United Nations in Geneva on Monday.

item.title: Minor Victory by Far-Right Party Has France Asking if Bigger Changes Are Ahead
item.description: The decisive victory underlined how the National Front’s tough talk on crime and illegal immigration may be resonating with voters.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Qaeda Suspect Is Brought to New York for a Hearing
item.description: Nazih Abdul-Hamed al-Ruqai, captured in Libya this month, was to be presented before a federal judicial officer on Tuesday after he stopped eating and drinking aboard a Navy vessel.
item.dc:creator: By BENJAMIN WEISER, CHARLIE SAVAGE and ERIC SCHMITT.

item.title: The Lede: Rampage in Moscow Unfolds on Camera
item.description: Video from Russian news sites and social networks showed rioting by Russian nationalists who chanted “White Power!” and “Russians Advance!” as they stormed a vegetable market in search of migrants in a working-class district.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Cholera Kills 1, Sickens 158 in 5 Mexican States
item.description: Mexican authorities say cholera has sickened 159 people, including one who died, and spread to four states and the capital. It is the first local spread of the disease since an outbreak that ended in 2001.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Lens Blog: Down a Road Less Traveled, Looking for the Still Heart of Russia
item.description: Inspired by a book written in 1790, a photographer set out to capture the vast differences between Russia’s cities and its hinterlands.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Moscow Police Round Up Targets of Riot at Market
item.description: A day after migrant workers were beaten and terrorized by rioters, officers detained about 1,200 of them to check for outstanding warrants.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Police in Moscow rounded up about 1,200 employees of a vegetable warehouse on Monday.

item.title: Britain Makes an Overture to Repair Ties With China
item.description: The country is hoping not to miss out on economic opportunities in China, which other European nations are courting.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: India Ink: Aam Aadmi Party Breaking the Rules of Identity Politics
item.description: The party that made a foray into politics on an anticorruption agenda, is trying to establish its secular credentials in the upcoming Delhi state elections, by fielding a Muslim candidate in a constituency with a majority Hindu population.
item.dc:creator: By SAI MANISH
item.media:description: Arvind Kejriwal, leader of the Aam Aadmi Party, with volunteers outside the party office in New Delhi on Oct. 1.

item.title: The Russia Left Behind
item.description: Along the highway between Moscow and St. Petersburg — a 12-hour trip by car — one sees great neglected stretches of land that seem drawn backward in time.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
